ATOM.VALUE: A lovely, dry vineyard-designated Orvieto Classico from one of the region's best producers. Delicious flavors of fig, green melon, pear, and light herb offer a refreshing respite when you've had one too many oaky whites.

Grechetto is the most distinctive and interesting of the five grape varieties used in Orvieto Classico. This wine offers a nice clean, refreshing taste of melon, pear, and anise. Pairs beautifully with fresh trout, calamari, or Ceasar salad.
This wonderfully aromatic Italian bubbly is bright, crisp, and just sweet enough to pair well with ripe fruit. Kosher for Passover.

Muller-Thurgau (Mew-lair Toor-gau) sounds suspiciously like a kind of sausage or a souped-up European racecar. In fact, itâ€™s usually a boring and bland German-designed grape variety that can be transformed into something sensuous and sublime in the hands of a talented winemaker such as Diego Bolognani.
This pale, bright and refreshing white from Italy's Adriatic coast is at its best now and over the next 12 months.
Clelia Romano Fiano di Avellino, Colli di Lapio
A complex, dry wine from the Campania region of Italy. Some believe the Fiano grape variety produces the most distinguished dry whites of southern Italy. Just 660 cases produced.
This mouthwatering white is perfect for casual entertaining and alfresco dining. Best now and over the next 12 months.
This is not your everyday white wine. Easy to drink and better than ever, Italian whites are on the rise. This citrusy Gavi would be a great match with creamy pasta dishes or a mushroom risotto.
Pinot Grigio blended from Northern Italian vineyards in the Trentino, Friuli, and Alto Adige regions. Fresh, lively, and full of melon and citrus fruits, the 1998
Danzante is a refreshing wine to enjoy with cold dishes and shellfish.

Moscato d'Asti is a perennial favorite among warm weather wines. Delicately sweet and delightfully frizzante (semi-sparkling), this seductive northern Italian white is naturally low in alcohol at only 5.5 percent.
